PROS:  excellent service, fun & funky ambiance.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
* 4.25 stars * 

-+- INTRO: 

Passed WBS many times before on bicycle & always thought it'd be a "phony" or overly Americanized sushi joint... but you can't judge a book by its cover, so last night, bearing coooold SF winds & pedaling on empty stomachs (empty stomachs that are ALWAYS craving sushi mind you), we decided to venture inside... 

-+- NUTSHELL: 

/ Sushi was very very good in my opinion 

/ Prices were very decent 

/ Services was *good* though I have to point out the one older lady employee who had a pretty negative attitude the whole time (which was obviously displeasing esp. when we had to interact with her) 

/ Atmosphere was great (tiny, intimate, well decorated). 

/ Took me a while looking on the menu for vegetable tempura before asking the waiter and discovering that they have it, though no where on the menu a la carte. Strange. 

/ Two other notes: They don't do salmon teryiaki (bummer!) & are cash only, just FYI. 

-+- CONCLUSION: 

I enjoyed the visit here and would definitely go back when in the Mission.
author: Kai S.

description:
this place would get 5 stars bc its good sushi for good prices BUT THEY DONT HAVE GINGER DRESSING ON A GREEN SALAD

what sushi place doesnt?!?!

all the vegan ones with pickled radishes, or eggplant, or fried tofu were very good.

the fish ones with salmon marinated with soy sauce and dill is PHENOMENAL !!!!!!!!!! the eel and fried crab were very very yum as all. 

cash only.
author: Samantha S.

description: My friends and I went hunting for food on Valencia and were being kind of picky until we ran into this place. It's remarkably good considering it's pretty cheap for sushi. I'd parrot the statement that the Early Bird Special is a great choice, as it's still cheap after 7 PM and it's pretty tasty. Between sampling the nigiri, maki and my friend's noodles, I was pretty happy with everything I ate without being wowed by anything. I couldn't exactly make heads or tails of the service; they managed to bring out salads, miso and two of our three meals very quickly, but then we had to wait a while before our friend's tempura and noodles showed up. Definitely would go again when I have more cash on me so I can sample more of their menu.
author: Xanda S.

description:
We Be Sushi?  really?  ok the name does grab you but maybe not in the best way, haha.  A couple of us were meeting up w/ a friend who lives in the Mission and wandered around for a bit until we agreed on Japanese.  My friend got the chirashi combo, which is a plate w/ rice and sashimi on top, nice big pieces.  I had a few rolls, the best was the spider roll (softshell crab).  Hamachi nigiri was decent.  

Menu was pretty comprehensive although the bento combos seemed to be on the pricy side, and only comes w/ california rolls!  Beers are cheap, $3.50 for the standard big 3, Kirin, Sapporo, and Asahi.  

Sushi is relatively cheap but u get what u pay for, it's mediocre pretty much.  Good place for run-of-the-mill sushi.
author: Chi N.

description:
I ventured to We Be Sushi not based on reviews or any other type of word-of-mouth advertising, but simply because it offers Southwest Rapid Rewards Dining Credits. Pure motives, I know. 

Despite my ulterior purposes, I was pleasantly surprised. WBS served a delicious salmon teriyaki in a quaint environment. The staff was friendly and the food was cheap. 

The (high) three-star rating stems from the lack of listed maki/special maki choices. I loved the prices and taste of what I have, but there weren't a ton of alternatives, which is something I always enjoy at sushi restaurants. 

OH...make sure to try some of the maguro sashimi, as it was thickly sliced and delicious. 

Also: they take credit cards (I'd seen some reviews saying this was a cash only place). Don't be fooled!
author: Tom A.

description: Decent food (re: good, but nothing fancy or out of the norm), gets busy and the staff can become overwhelmed, but they are nice, good prices for sushi, reasonably fast. It's a good little local spot for reliable sushi. It's got a dive-ish feel, but it's clean and they have one of the better seaweed salad's in SF. It's small, so don't plan on having a group gathering here, but that's fine by me. I like my local sushi spot.
author: K H.

description:
After waking past this joint about  million times, we finally decided to check it out yesterday and boy are we glad we did.  Sushi in this city can be really expensive, but We Be Sushi has great prices for great rolls.  We had sake, wine and 4 rolls and walked out only $30! 
The service was also friendly and fast and we didn't have to wait for a table, even at 630 on a Saturday eve.
author: Carlos W.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." About sums it up. 

I'm still on the search for my new sushi place within walking distance of my new place, with no luck. 

I tried to evaluate this place on the basis that it is cheap, and I mean really cheap. $3 Nigiri?

Well, you get what you pay for. All the food tastes like plastic. The spinach salad had brown leaves and all the sushi had this weird smell... I can't really place it, but lemme tell you it wasn't appetizing. 

The service was ok, but there were two servers working there and they seemed to be competing with each other. They would try to take that same parts of our order twice. It's a small place and you'd think they could try to coordinate. 
 
I understand that cheap sushi is cheap, not amazing. But this was not edible.
author: Kealie G.

description: One star for being inexpensive! Another star for the friendly, earnest staff. Sushi was a bit odd, and looked old. It tasted alright and I didn't get sick though, so all's good. If a sushi place was a dive-bar though, I think this would be it. It has its place in the community. I probably won't be back though. This review sounds pretentious, doesn't it? Ugh. I'm just a little bit particular about my sushi...
author: Heidi H.

description:
Im going to downgrade my review of  We Be Sushi to three stars. 

 Why? The last time we went it was really disappointing, the fish was sort of stale, the service was TERRIBLE (all the waitresses were different, what happened?)  and well, we found a new "value sushi" restaurant= Sushi San on Lombard... which is a fantastic deal when you use the Restaurant.com coupon.     Maybe next time we go back they can redeem themselves???  we'll see....
author: Carol P.

description:
Not a place I'd go unless I'd been drinking.  Fortunately, I had.  

The tables are close enough together that you can scare your neighbors with your conversation, and you gotta appreciate the decor's funk factor, which is notably absent from new restaurants on Valencia (cough*dosa*cough*osha*cough).  

The fish is kinda skinny and the food fairly generic, but the one-of-a-kind maki, with tempura shrimp and spicy tuna all rolled up together... that made the whole trip worth it.
author: Dana S.

description:
We Be Sushi is good for what it is-- cheap sushi. You have to try their spider rolls. It's the real thing, maybe better. Generous pieces of soft shell crab (not greasy at all) tucked in with avocado slices and other yummy things. Very simple but tasty. Their salmon skin rolls are good too-- crispy and tasty salmon skin goes well with the taste of seaweed and sushi rice. 

Sashimi is okay. Nothing fancy and thinly sliced. Their miso soup is good.  My parents like the salmon avocado rolls. 

It's a very small place so I like to get it to go if I need a quick sushi fix. You can eat a good deal of food for about 15 dollars per person if you order right.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
This place is a pretty small hole in the wall. Hence, waiting for a table of 3 took way longer than it would be if we'd only been 2 people.

Their dinner menu was expensive, only because we arrived after the happy hour had already finished. This isn't to say, however, that the quality of their rolls and fish wasn't excellent.

I got the dragon roll and some regular tuna to go with it. Both were really good. The dragon roll didn't skimp on the eel whatsoever and was impressively displayed on my plate. The tuna sashimi was fresh, and came in a pretty generous portion. 

Overall this place was really enjoyable, but I'll shop around some more before I go back.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Not the best sushi I've ever had, but quite good, and for the price, excellent.

Salmon was the best, and for $14, the nigiri/maki combination plate with miso was a great deal.  Nothing horribly creative on the maki side, but fresh fish, prepared well.  I'm already looking forward to going back.
author: Ryan L.

description:
It was ok.  I didn't much like the mayo type sauce they put it in the spicy tuna roll. And this place doesn't serve hamachi kama or qalbi short ribs which was disappointing.

The deep fried shrimp heads were good.
author: Kym P.

description: Really poor quality fish, surprised they are allowed to make sushi with that. I got little sick after eating it.
author: ferhat n.

description:
Poppy's go to place when she's craving cheap decent sushi.

There's always room and service is lovely.  Hot tea and tasty miso soup.

Drinks like mom used to mix indeed.
author: Poppy C.

description: I really enjoyed my first visit here. I was deciding on sake and Abby ended up bringing out a few for me to try and was really helpful and attentive.  The sushi is super cheap and it tastes good. Definitely will be back!
author: Dakota H.

description:
A friend and I decided to eat here after walking up and down the streets of Valencia searching for a place to eat. The name of the restaurant caught our eyes.

What really struck me is that their miso soup has more than just tofu and seaweed. (Sounds lame, I know!) But there are carrots and onions in there too (I believe) and I've never seen any other restaurant do that. I ordered the unagi donburi and it was overflowing in unagi. There was a layer of unagi sitting on top of the rice bowl, and the more I ate, I discovered that there was a layer of unagi hidden in the middle of the bowl too. Definitely well worth the money.
author: Lily Z.

description:
Okay, the sushi was great - not the best EVER, but really can't complain - it was truly GOOD, fresh, satisfying. I would go back!

What I didn't like was the attitude I felt I was getting when we first got inside. The lady serving us seemed a bit bothered by the presence of me and my friends for a bit (we arrived at 9:30 and they close at 10). Fortunately, the lady serving us apologized "if we felt rushed" toward the end of the evening, and I totally forgave her. i know how it is to have people come in toward closing time... but you know, the restaurant is still open and it shouldn't be clear to the patrons that a server is bothered that you came in close to closing time, in my opinion.

eh... there you have it
author: Jason B.

description:
Been drawn to the promise of sushi like my mom used to make for awhile now and finally succumbed recently.

Eh. Not surprising, though, since Mom was never great at making sushi either.

It's a homey place. Charming inside. But the fish wasn't awesome. It was actually a little fishy. Not so much as to complain, but so much as to say "Oh yeah, that's why it's that price." 

You get what you pay for. Nothing more and not really less, either.
author: Will R.

description: So far so good. Our server was cute and attentive and they appear to have great lunch and happy hour specials. We got regular and special rolls and both were good- above average for the price range. The small space and decor are kitschy and refreshingly different than hip sushi places. The miso soup has carrots in it... never had that before, but I liked it.
author: Alex A.

description: This place was so bad, it was funny! I ordered the "we be sushi roll", that was supposed to come with tuna and cream cheese. It came with this nasty looking black fish and cucumber. I asked the waitress if my order was correct and she said "yes, it's correct. This fish with cream cheese taste horrible, so we changed it to cucumber". But I hate cucumbers!!!! And the fish was horrible regardless of what it was paired with!!! Tasted like rotten fish that has been sitting on the trash for a few days... Argh! I told her I wasn't going to eat it because it tasted really bad, and she charged me for it! I felt I was being pranked :-) soooo bad!!!!
author: Carolina A.

description: I work in the neighborhood and come here for quick healthier lunches instead of the average mexican or pizza 30 min lunch rush. I am a loyal customer and always tip graciously, even with small purchases. Note to the business owners/ servers: lets not get stingy when it comes to loyalty apps. If you agree to have Belly at your establishment, your agreeing to reward customers for their loyalty. I bought a 5 dollar fast roll on my lunch break and was told I could not use the Belly app if my purchase was under $10 dollars. Another trip, I earned a 25 point seaweed salad and was told I could not get my salad until I reached 5 points more. Even though I spent 6 dollars today, I would have come back for more meals and would have brought friends for dinner. Instead, I have decided that this will be my last lunch as We Be Sushi because I am tired of dealing with the confrontation about a loyalty app they decided to offer.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Friend of mine took me here for dinner, as she goes here every so often for lunch since she works nearby.

The sushi was a-okay, to be honest.  Maybe I shouldn't have ordered rolls that were waaaay out there, which is why I was kinda meh on the whole experience.

The spicy tuna/tempura roll though was pretty good, of the three I ordered.  I forgot the rest, but they didn't seem as great.

At least it was pretty cheap, nothing wrong with that though.
author: Ren L.

description:
I finally found a place worthy of a three star review!

The food was edible, and reasonably priced for sushi, but it is definitely not the best sushi place in the city.

I had the tuna salad roll, and the one of a kind roll, and they weren't good, However, i watched the sushi chef making a bunch of other rolls, and they looked good. I think i just picked wrong.

It's a decent hole in the wall (yes, it's a hole in the wall. That place is TINY!

They are cash only.
author: Weyl E.

description:
Too bad this place is kinda gross: it's the closest one!

I can't think of a time I have been satisfied here, and they are so darn expensive! The fish often seems dry and lackluster. I don't know if this is a freshness issue or if they just buy cheap stuff. I have ordered rolls (super costly and oversauced), sashimi (occasionally yummy, but too infrequently so to risk it), and nigiri (usually not awful). The salads are weird with sugary dressings, and the Miso is uber salty. Service is usually kind and attentive, but it cannot make up for the disappointment I always feel, especially when it comes time to pay up.

I'd rather eat a can of tuna on the bus than return to We Be Sushi.
author: Jenny H.

description:
The WeBeNoodles (soba) were the most boring noodles I've had and quite possibly the most expensive ($10). The broth tasted like watered-down french onion and the noodles themselves were sparse.

The sushi lunch meal ($8) was passable, but definitely not memorable. The only thing here that seemed like it could have come from a Tokyo sushi joint was the miso soup.

Final word: if you're on Valencia, you will have plenty of better options in either direction.
author: Andrew B.

description:
I've lived in the city now for a year, and it took me this long to try this place, a couple blocks from my place. I think it was the ridiculous name that scared me off all this time. But then again, Sushi Bistro, the king of all sushi joints in the city, has a pretty un-sushi name too.

I got the early bird special, which turned out to be pretty decent. I don't know what kind of cooked fish was in the Valencia roll, but it was dry and chewy but decent-tasting. I got the hamachi for the 5-piece nigiri, which was okay. The soup was good, as was the seaweed salad. With a Sapporo, everything came to a little over $12.

Good enough where I'd do this again. A nice go-to place for no-frills sushi. Good, friendly service too.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I'd eat here frequently specifically for the chicken teriyaki... until, the recipe and portion changed drastically. The other menu items are not bad.
author: Casey M.

description:
I know there are two locations, but this is the only one I ever go to.
I have been coming here since I was a kid, It's where I learned to use chopsticks.  They are the spot if you are looking for super cheep, yet acceptable sushi.
Their fish is always very fresh, and the people are so nice.  
I really like their Hamachi, and their Shiro Maguro, and seaweed salad.  
Also the NY roll reverse with tobiko is super good.
Early bird special is an awesome deal for $8
author: Liz A.

description: Been coming to WeBe since it was on Geary Blvd. (those were the days) and still love it
author: EJ T.

description: I've been coming to this small neighborhood sushi place since I was a kid- It's always impeccably quirky, with anything but Japanese music playing (and that's part of why I love it- Sushi and salsa music? So surreal!). The food is super reasonable and fresh. I like the lunch special and kappa-maki is one of my favorites.
author: Jessica M.

description: This place is cute, n the server are so friendly n nice... I'd recommend to fam/frnds the price are reasonable the only downsize is, they need to make their sushi a little bigger... But, other then that its good food!!
author: Rosie A.

description:
The tragedy about Yelp and sushi is that the restaurants in the area seem to get more credit than they should for "ambiance" and the music they play, presentation, booze, etc.  Come on people, this is not as important as the food.  If you want your restaurants all slick and soaked in pleasant ambiance, move to Orange County or San Diego.  I understand if you're the type to make a soaking paste with your soy and wasabi, but if you like to taste the fish (but not fish-y) places like this should be coming out on top.  

Anyway - this place teeters on 3 and 4 stars, but for the difficulty of finding good, reasonably priced sushi in the city.  I've been to a few places so far and this is the first one where the sushi is all relatively good, reasonably priced and the service is decent.  The miso is good, the sake selection is also good and inexpensive, and every piece we had was of good quality.
author: Scott S.

description:
I've passed by this place many times over the years and finally went with my girl this past Friday.  We sat down and two ladies were leaving the table next to us.  One of the ladies started talking to us and immediately asked how the sex was.  She had been living abroad for a few years and really liked that she could just strike up conversations with people in English.  Anywho...

The rolls are very good especially for the price.  The Workman roll really stood out in my mind;  healthy and filling.  Top that off with some hot sake and we walked out of there for $30.
author: Corey V.

description: Im a solid supporter, although the food itself is mediocre, the place is cute and usually the service is very earnest.  Ill go here for the Early Bird Special anytime.
author: Dressing F.

description:
Solid 4 stars. Sushi was fresh and flavorful. SPICY spicy tuna but heavy with the mayo. The Salmon in Dill is good and I echo the cooked fish rolls aren't the absolute best. Seaweed salad and miso were the best ever. Service was fast and friendly and it felt very cozy. What really knocks this place out of the park is AFFORDABILITY BABY!!!

3 rolls, 1 sea weed salad, 2 large beers about 30 bucks.

This is the new sushi spot for me!
author: Allegra F.

description:
I had to debate whether it was justified to knock down a whole star for "cash only" at a small mom-and-pop place. Until I realized I would have been rounding way up to three stars anyway. 

Given that this is San Francisco, and hence, on the ocean and with plentiful access to various ways of getting fresh fish, the sushi was adequate. Pieces were tasty, but not abundant. Rolls were fresh and creative. 

Not a destination spot, but good for neighborhood eats. Having to run out to find an ATM? Booo....
author: Da J.

description:
This place is okay in a pinch, for when you're _really_ craving sushi, but I always leave here feeling like I just took a risk I probably shouldn't have.
The cut of fish isn't ever quite as good as I want it to be, and the rolls are always fairly bland. The service is okay, I guess, but I always feel a bit like I'm putting someone out for asking for food in return for my money.
In any case, this place definitely doesn't break the bank, but I could say the same about Safeway, which is pretty much of equal quality, when all is said and done.
author: Erin P.

description: I wanted to find a sushi place with good sushi with a reasonable price. This is place is small and cozy. I ordered 3 is a crowd roll with mangro rolls. They are just right amount to fill my stomach. It came along with delicious miso soup. If you want something more, seaweed salad is something you could go for. Just too good. It comes in reasonable price compared to other sushi places. Oh yeah, It is cash only. Also, waitresses are friendly. I took several of my friends there and they said that place is great place to go!
author: C.D. H.

description: We accidently stumbled in here trying to use a scoutmob deal (turns out it was for the other location) but ended up really liking this place. The atmosphere was GREAT, servers friendly and attentive and the food was very high value. We were glad to make the mistake and plan to return.
author: M L.

description:
I absolutely love Webe sushi, every time I visit I leave both happy and satisfied. The sushi is quite good, though I have had better, but it's one of the best sushi _values_ that I have encountered anywhere. 
The Staff are friendly, and if you visit a few times it's easy to turn into a regular.
Webe has become one of my touchstone restaurants, One that I re-visit constantly.
author: Harry P.

description:
I learned two things the night I dined here:

First and foremost, romantic memories of childhood love are often best left in the past.  DO NOT "CATCH UP" WITH YOUR SWEETHEART FROM WHEN YOU WERE 14.  That was the major note of the night.

Secondly, if you're trying to impress a Mari C., don't: 
a.) order "us" sake even after I say I don't really like it
b.) order the Sayuri sake (the girliest *pink* drink I've ever seen.  Tastes like fermented perfume)
c.) continue to consume the entire bottle by yourself, get completely drunk, and leave your date sober and unimpressed.

So that was basically my night.  My memory of the guy was once something like this:
http://www.clamack.hpg.ig.com.br/ATORES/JonathanTaylorThomas/JonathanTaylorThomas028.jpg

Now, it appears more like this:
http://mako.cc/copyrighteous/images/hackergotchi-02.jpg

The sushi was alright I guess.  Except for the stench of nostalgia dying before my eyes.
author: Mari C.

description: Decent little sushi place, it's actually only the third time I've had sushi that I can recall, and suffice to say I was not disappointed. My tuna rolls came out great - however their real gem seemed to be the mango rolls. I'll return at some point in the future I hope.. It seems worthy of me trying something different next time, perhaps unagi.
author: Terry B.

description: Food was very mediocre. Service was good though. I ordered White Tuna and it was not the freshest or highest quality by any means. I also ordered a "One Kind of Roll" which is supposed to be shrimp tempura and spicy tuna. It came and was nothing more than a roll with a small amount of deep fried shrimp. If you pulled out a microscope you could see some sort of spicy sauce in some of the pieces. I said something and after a little bit of translation issues the point was made and they were happy to redo the roll for me. The second roll had more "spicy tuna" but it was mostly a spicy mayo sauce. I would not go back here but I am glad that they respected the customer enough to try to fix the problem. Also it came with a miso soup that was not too good. The seaweed was like a slime.
author: Josh V.

description:
Sure it's not the fanciest place in the neigborhood, but where else can you roll in, sit down, and get a sushi special with a big beer and sake for less than twenty bucks?
Service was great, coziness factor (read: narrow room, high ceiling) was...cozy, and it wansn't too loud.
I got the house special with nigiri and some roll with tuna- forgot the name.  Both very fresh and tasty.  Miso soup and spinach salad were above average.  
Super value.  Love it.
author: Eric S.

description: This has been one of our favorite restaurants in the Mission for many years - tremendously friendly staff, delicious sushi and cooked salmon lunches and dinners (extremely affordable), great deal all around. If you want fancy rolls and fru fru saki go someplace else. Sure, the service is laid back. No Big deal. The staff pays attention if you say you're in a hurry or need something.  I have no idea why this place isn't completely packed every day of the week - we enjoy it so much.
author: Kathryn S.

description:
It is small, know that from the get go at this location.

The sushi is akin to Safeway sushi boxes, in size, however it tastes WAY BETTER.

But the prices match it, so it's great if you want a quick sushi fix, and a variety of thinks.  The Sashimi is always fresh and good, and the sake selection is small, but affordable.

I say this is great if you just want to hang out, have a nice Sunday evening sushi session, and still keep your wallet intact when it's all said and done!
author: Wel S.

description:
I think that "We Be Sushi" is one of the 1st cheap sushi place in town in the middle of 80's.
In 80's, 
it was good idea but who still wants to go there in 2006, for crying out loud.
Cheap piece of crap done by Japanese.
Make Sushi like fast food.
I read the sign in this store says, "We wanted to put the name as McSushi."
McSushi!?
That's retarded.
Shame on you, dumb ass!
Cheap shit-imitate crap sushi,
author: Nobu K.

description:
N-N-N Narly! Walking along the mission streets hours later Mr. says "I just wish I could throw it up!" I say, "Yes, don't you wish we could do it all over again. They could take away the calories, the fullness and we could eat all over again...except somewhere good."

Oh mercy, the worst are the rolls. I looked down on my spring blossom roll and I was a little afraid. It reminds me of the stuff you buy in bulk. I took a bite "Grocery store sushi," I told my friend. "Fucking Safeway!"

We were peeved. We also got Hamachi Kama which was breaded. We were trying to avoid such foods and were rather disappointed to have some fatty stuff in our diet BUT at least the portions were good. Hmm...
author: Alexandra M.

description: I love this place. The early bird special is a bomb deal and Waneda is awesome and I LOVE her. the owners are sweet and I just all around think this place is great. My husband and I used to come here weekly for our omega intake. now I come from berkeley in to get delish sushi :)
author: Marit K.

description:
I'm a fan because this place is really close to my house and cozy enough that I'd feel comfortable taking a date here.  It's not fancy and the food is not ridiculously good, but I love how small it is.
A roll + crazy combination soup + 2 small bottles of hot sake + tempura = $27
Cheap.  I dig it.
author: Meh M.

description:
pass.... 
So so service.  So So food. I wanted to like it I really did.  
I gave it a second star because it was cheap.
author: Christopher F.

description:
Yergh. We be sushi? More like we be forgettable pieces of carrots and rice wrapped in soggy seaweed. Oh, and we be super tiny sushi that costs way too much. We be not satisfied. We not coming back. 

(Yes, I meant to do that.)
author: Michelle G.

description:
I can't judge this place fairly.  My hot date blinders were up so everything looked amazing to me.  

That being said, we stopped in here because we were starving and it was right across the street.  The wait was all of two minutes, but they had us wait outside (that seemed really cute at the time...).  

We ordered mostly vegetarian items, but I also had a Rock n Roll.  Despite other reviews of this place, I found all of the food to be far beyond "just barely edible" on the scale of goodness.  Was I distracted by the person sitting in front of me?  Maybe.  But it didn't seem as bad as people are suggesting.  We were a little thrown by the variety of rolls featuring parmesan cheese (they get bumped down a star just for that).

And, the decor is cute in a funky, hole-in-the-wall way.  Everyone had their tea in these random corporate mugs and the walls are covered in random things.

All and all, it's cheap, the food is decent, and the place has some charm to it.  I wouldn't go if there was a wait, but it's far from the worst sushi I've had.
author: Katie S.

description:
3 1/2

We Be Sushi is about as good as it gets when it comes to sushi in the Mission. Quick, not too dirty, good-tasting, and served with a slight smile, even.

I'm not telling you, by any means, to go to this one, between 21st and 22nd on Valencia, over the location down toward 16th. No, you didn't just hear that from me. Srsly, go to that one.

That said, I cannot vouch for the 16th/Valencia edition of We Be.

Nothing too fancy here: A couple of signature rolls, standard-fare nigiri, maki, and sashimi. But what I like are the details. Miso with every order; hot, salted edamame; no ice-cream-scoop-size wasabe.

So, when you're in the Mission and looking for cheap, solid sushi, go here, or, you know, to the one by 16th.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Cute place, nice vibe, but unfortunately the worst sushi I have eaten in the city so far.

The rice was soggy and mushy. The fish wasn't much better. The other location next to Puerta Allegre is better. 

If you really want good sushi, try Amasia.
author: Will N.

description:
They open at 11:45am, and they've got a nice vegetarian special, with miso soup, seaweed salad (if you want it), and other accoutrements, and if you order tea with it, the total with tip comes to like $8, which is ridiculously cheap for something fairly tasty.

And the service is great.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
The sushi here rocks for the price.
I have to say though that the cooked food that I've had here not only takes forever to come, but seems always to be very dry.
Whatever, what kind of dumb ass orders chicken teriyaki when there is sushi to be had?
Me, that's boo-who.
:-(
author: Theo R.

description:
"Fried crunchy tempura lard roll, please!"

My dad is all about efficiency. He likes to eat dinner at 4PM. Nothing else was even open for our "earliest of birds" escapade, so here we were. 

Dad also doesn't care about the quality of the fish as long the rolls come fried and drenched in mayo sauce. Mission accomplished. He was very impressed. $40 later we still had 20 minutes left on the meter.

As for me, unless I'm craving sushi at the time when ALL other restaurants are in siesta, I doubt I'll ever return.
author: Carrie R.

description:
I'm rating this mostly on the happy-hour, though the normal prices and everything are fine.

This is my sushi happy hour spot. For $7.95, you get steamed rice, miso soup, seaweed salad (or spinach if you have no taste in good food), a six-piece Valencia roll and YOUR CHOICE of five-piece Nigiri sushi.

It's a lot of freaking food, and I've never been able to finish it. ...and it's good. Soooo super wonderful amazin' tastin'. 

There are decent vegetarian options, too. They weren't too finicky when my vegetarian friend wanted to substitute a veggie roll instead. She seemed pleased :)

The atmosphere is pretty nifty, too. Lots of neat-o things on the walls, interesting posters, unique artwork. It's cozy as hell, too, and I absolutely love the door (the type where you can open the top or the bottom or both). 

I imagine it's pretty busy at night, though. I can't be sure...the one time I went at night, I was pretty drunk.

So it goes.
author: Danyell K.

description:
We Be Sushi is a great place to get high-quality, reasonably priced sushi.

The restaurant wasn't very busy when we got there on a Sunday evening, and we were seated immediately. My boyfriend and I had never tried sake before, and the waitress was very nice about helping us select one to try. 

We had the Philadelphia roll, rock'n roll, and fried California roll with sour cream and hot sauce. All three were delicious, but the fried California roll was definitely the best. 

After dinner, we had an order (two pieces) of green tea mochi ice cream, which was also excellent. 

In the end, dinner, sake, and mochi ice cream for two cost $40, including tax and tip.

My only complaint is that we never received the complimentary miso soup we were offered, but I left We Be Sushi stuffed regardless. I would definitely recommend this restaurant!
author: Deanna M.

description: I have been going to both locations for the last ten years and they are yum. The price is right and the service is great! It's a great neighborhood place and if you find yourself in the neighborhood, you should go!
author: Rachel A.

description:
I was so excited to have sushi close to my house and then I was so sad. It is by far the worst sushi, 2nd only to something I bought in a 7-11 in the valley once. Having to walk by it everyday and having my dream of a sushi restaurant a mere block away and then, alas no, it is just crap on a plate. When people describe it as being in someones kitchen I think they mean the part of someones kitchen like the crisper drawer that has been ignored for months. (Is that an eggplant?)
The food is gross and the opposite of fresh. The prices are seriously cheap. I would have been really mad if it was expensive and that gross. I do not know anyone that actually likes it there, and I know people that will eat anything.
author: Autumn R.

description:
I love the early bird special, 5 pieces of Nigiri (your choice), one roll, miso and seaweed salad. Perfect meal and all for $7.95.
Great, unpretentious sushi in the mission.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
The name says it all. 

Great prices on sushi with a fun atmosphere (I kinda felt like their was a fishing village not too far off.)  Many of the rolls are eccentric with things like philly cream cheese or parmesan cheese mixed in.  The cream cheese is surprisingly refreshing on spicy rolls.

The nigiri however leaves much to be imagined.  Tuna was a bit hard as if it was sitting out all day (i tend to prefer tuna soft, and not baked under overhead lighting.)

Food quality: 2 stars for nigiri, 3-4 stars for the rolls
Atmosphere: 5 starts
Price: 5 starts
author: Vinnie L.

description: Cozy nice place. The price is good and the food is good. Variety choice of veggie sushi:)
author: Maitai N.

description:
This place has a completely different ownership than the We Be at 16th. Only the brand is the same. (Both used to be owned by the same people, who broke it up and sold the parts.)

It's also marginally better than the We Be up the street, so I'd like to give it 4 stars, but it still doesn't quite make it that high. Mediocre sushi at a great price -- like it's sibling, this location is "good enough", and this is where I'll go if I'm closer to this end of Valencia and don't feel like heading deeper into the Mission.
author: Charlie Bolognese Z.

description:
I swore I would never eat here because of the name and the multiple locations - it made me think of McDonalds.  One night before seeing a play at the Marsh I hungrily stumbled in, and it was actually OK.  Better than No Name sushi, and they serve alcohol here.
The staff is nice, service is friendly and quick, and the food is cheap.  Only order rolls here, do not order nigiri.  I still think of this like McDonalds sushi - quick, cheap, and tasty enough.
author: Deann F.

description:
Danger. Danger Will Robinson. The sushi is awful here. There is no taste to the rice and the fish is not fresh. Perfect fodder for a stomach ache. I think my last visit was the first time I didn't eat all my sushi.

We Be Sushi. You'll Be Ilin'.
author: Robert C.

description:
The place looks totally cool, with a fun, quirky Japanese-style interior.  I love the "we Be Sushi" 7up sign outside the place, too.  Friendly staff, and this place is as affordable as sushi gets in SF.  

Sushi snobs will probably think the quality misses the mark a bit.  But, to be honest, I think if you're new to the sushi scene or not that picky, you probably won't mind and you'll enjoy the fun atmosphere.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I'm actually angry about the dinner I had a We Be Sushi.

I'd heard good things from friends, and I love the name, so I picked it out as a place for a casual Monday night meet-up with some friends.  We were kind of in a rush, so I just ordered the house sushi dinner plate.

The service was warm and friendly and I found the mixmatched dinnerware endearing.  Our waitress was accomodating and sweet.  Although the mariachi band the filled the small establishment with their tinny wails for 15 minutes kind of put a damper on the conversations/inner thought process of humans.  I kind of wish the staff at We Be Sushi had maybe not let them in.  But then again, I just moved to The Mission, so for all I know mariachi bands are to SF what the Sopranos are to NJ, and the owners of We Be Sushi owe them a favor.

Anyway, my anger at the meal was 99% a result of the "food."  The tuna sushi was stringy, and the little nub of rice it was laying upon lacked cohesiveness and fell apart at the touch of my chopsticks.  And the house roll...I have no idea what it was.  Perhaps some sort of fish jerky and cream cheese and oshinko?  It tasted like a cat treat.  It was so contrived and dressed up and not even close to what I expect when I go out to eat sushi.  (My friend ordered a roll with Parmesan cheese!  Ew!)

While my entire meal, plus Beer, only cost me $10, I was sorely dissappointed and pretty grossed out.  It doesn't matter what your place looks like, how big or small or fancy, because at the end of the day, people come there for good, fresh sushi and We Be Sushi simply does not deliver.
author: Melanie D.

description:
cheap food thats okay tasting. Their green salad is probably my favorite.
also, they always have AMAZING music playing. I love listening to belle and sebastian, beach house, etc...while dining 

The  waiting service is really excellent. There is one waitress who is very groovy. I love her style. 

Rant:

I am pretty much never going there because of the RUDE sushi chef (and owner maybe?) who thirty minutes before they closed refused to serve me. I tried to explain that I was a regular and eat very quick, I was even ALONE! He wasn't having it and very rudely just said that they were closed already. (the rest. had a couple of tables filled and they were still preparing food.  Meh, no big loss. I only went there because of the cheap soba and good service. I rather go to crazy sushi where the service is great, the soba is tasty and prices are just as cheap.

sorry for the grammar mistakes...im tired.
author: hi boss hi wife a.

description: I think this place is awesome. Maybe I am easily impressed, or maybe I just like nice people and good food. Whatever the case, this place has some pretty nice people. I walked in pretty late one night to satisfy my sushi craving and just order to go. The staff was super friendly and gave me a table while I waited. Now I have worked at a restaurant before and if they give you water for a to go order they are already going the extra mile. Usually servers don't care about to go's because there usually  isn't a tip for them, so why would they want to take a table and get taxed for it on their paycheck? Well this guy gave me some water and some soup and checked up on me halfway in being super nice the whole time. No lie, the place is small, but in a way cozy, and I think nice people like that make the world go round. The food was reasonably priced and tasted real good too. I definitely recommend at least peeking inside and checking the place out. It has a real cool ambiance to it.
author: Dan B.

description:
Its bad.  When your trademark roll tastes like dogshit with cream cheese, its time to throw in the towel.

Gets an extra star for low prices and friendly service.
author: Jackson R.

description:
This place is very easy to sum up:

GOOD:  For sushi, this place is cheap as hell.  Great for cheap-eats sushi.

BAD:  No dessert menu.  I always need something sweet after a really salty meal.

UGLY:  No credit cards?  What the sh*t?
author: Ankur P.

description:
Cash-only places mean only one thing: mafia.

Well, the Mexican yakuza working here be making some good sushi at reasonable prices. Not many decent Japanese restaurants in the Mission. But if you're pregnant or have an urge for sushi, We Be Sushi will do the trick.

Their cold sake selection is actually pretty darn good. I love me some cold draft sake!  (^_^)V

I gave them an extra star for their cool name. I woulda given them another one if they had named it "We Be Sushin' "    

~T
author: Tomas V.

description: Not too bad of a place. Prices are reasonable and I always get great service when i'm there. The sushi isn't too shabby. I have had fresher and better presentation plates of sushi before. I def will hit this place up again because the prices are nice...and I always get me some warm saki to kick off the night right
author: Mr. Potato G.

description:
This place is actually worse than death. I'd rather die then go here again. The sushi is horrendous and we waited 90 minutes for our food. 90 minutes people! This place was actually the 80s lovechild of Gordon Gekko and the Crypt Keeper.

AVOID!
author: Tyler W.

description:
Affordable, good sushi. Tasty selections. Courteous service. What's there not to like? 

Blink and you'll miss it. I haven't been to the others, but this particular location is petite. Found on the same street as a bicicyle shop and a mom and pop record store this joint doesn't attract the attention of those who wouldn't otherwisingly know it's there. Not that it has to anyway.

If you're looking for a sushi place that will help you establish your inner zen, look elsewhere. Depending on what time of the day you go, there may be a slight wait.  It gets pretty cramped inside and fills up really quickly. Expect to bump elbows with the person seated at the table next to you. 

Nevertheless it's worth it. Yum is all I have to say. Try the yellowtail. It's the best I've had so far.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
When No-name sushi disappeared, (and unfortunately, the freshness and the service started to dwindle before its closing) I fell back on my plan B, which is WeBe.

There is primarily one reason alone why I love this place, and that is the white fatty tuna. (And it is described that way on the menu, to avoid confusion) Its texture and taste are superb. I find the rest of the sushi to be also be good, but I should say that, despite the fact I have been eating sushi for about 3/4 of my life, I am hardly a connoisseur. Im a big fan of their miso as well.

Despite the fact the place is small, even on crowded nights with a packed house, it doesn't feel annoying. The staff have always been nice, and are pretty good about keeping the sake coming.

Yah, it's good. Definitely my number one choice for a sushi night.
author: Jonny P.

description:
I ate here for lunch yesterday with a friend, and we were very pleased.  Now, I love sushi, and normally, I throw down $30-40 on specialty rolls, unless there are good bento box options.  The menu to me seemed limiting and not organized very well, but they had lunch specials $8-11, and both of us decided to go for the tempura lunch.  It came with 9 pieces (4 shrimp, 5 veggie) of perfect tempura, and both of our special rolls (spicy tuna roll, and dragon-maki) were top notch, and i normally hate spicy tuna rolls.  The sheer amount of tempura made this entire trip worth it.

I would definitely come back for lunch, probably to get the same thing!
author: Nathan R.

description:
The sushi is OK, I've certainly had better, but I've also had worse. The place itself is tiny, and cute, but the rolls were tiny and lackluster. The nigiri on the other hand was delicious. I love hamachi and 2 pieces of that was 2.75, a pretty fair price in my opinion.

We came on a cold night and people kept forgetting to close the door, so there were alot of times during dinner where we had to close the door or freeze to death, maybe the door can be fixed somehow?

The real redeeming factor for the night was the waitress. She was so cute, and helpful. Hell, her alone deserves 2 stars! I'm not sure how the sushi selection in the Mission is (besides Tokyo a go-go), but if I'm hankering for sushi and I'm in the area, I'll semi-reluctantly come here.
author: Rocky K.

description: I went once for a lunch special.  Ok prices.  Good sushi.  No complaints.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Some mixed reviews here... Hmmm might have been the night of the week or who knows what. But I love fresh fish. Have had my share and can say this. That my experiences here have been great. Andy-san the owner has takes pride in his work and makes good sushi available to the masses at great prices. For those of you who like no-name on Church and think they are a good buy think again. We Be is good fish at a good price and great service. 

My two cents.
author: Stephanie I.

description: We went to the Marsh for a live theater performance and ducked in here for a bite beforehand. The handmade sushi was delicious and reasonably-priced.
author: Paula H.

description:
My co workers and I frequent this place for lunch a lot. It's reasonably priced and the food's quality is good for what you pay for.  The server lady is always nice to us as well, and now that we're regulars we always look forward to seeing her when we come.
Don't come in here expecting premium quality sushi though. It's not a fancy sushi bar, nor does it pretend to be. There are plenty of other places you can go to in the Mission if that's what you're looking for, but We Be is perfectly good for what it is.
author: Aletta W.

description:
Dependable but average.  Average but dependable?

I appreciate the clean decor, cozy environment, & prompt service, but nothing on the menu stands out.  I'd lump it in with Crazy Sushi on 16th as having the same food quality level. 

It's not bad, it's just not something I would go out of my way to get -- especially in the Mission.
author: Tim G.

description:
Sushi was definitely decent for its price... meaning it was CHEAP. Their service was okay. It's pretty cozy in there. So, leave your giant-sized LV bag at home. I thought it was real San Francisco-like. 

ADVISORY:
Don't talk about something you wouldn't want to share with strangers, because your table neighbors will definitely hear what you're talking about.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
Oh, We Be Sushi, why must you be cash only?

This is the sushi place I come to most often, but mostly by default because it's the closest one to my house.

I'm not much of a sushi expert so I can't really comment there, but they've got the usual: ebi, unagi, uni, kappa, etc. Nothing spectacular.

They always serve miso soup.

P.S. My uni is better.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I have been here twice now for lunch and I am not going back. Yes, the food is cheap, but unless you are absolutely broke and have no issues with mushi textured rice, slighltly odorous fish and very odd flavored miso- then why subject yourself to an unquestionably subpar meal? 

I would rather go to Taco Bell (when the budget is tight) than attempt to save money on a cheaper plate of sushi. At least then I would know exactly what I am getting. ICK!!!
author: SF U.

description: I stopped here because I noticed the awesome dinner special ad in the window.  I had an ell roll and some nigiri.  While the special was good, the food unfortunately wasn't that great.  Unsatisfying and unpleasant.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
I don't care what anyone says, I love We-Be Sushi. I have been going here consistently  for the last six years of my life and they are what I like to call my "Sushi Staple"

Quite often I use them for takeout, since waiting lengthy amounts of time for one of their ten tables (I don't know the exact seating capacity, but it's a small place) isn't always appealing. They're cheap, clean, quick and dependable. Sometimes I want fresh-made sushi that isn't too done up and isn't going to break my bank. I need a little variety when I'm on a budget and We-Be fills that need. I prefer the no-frills spot near Boogaloos in the Outer Mission as opposed to the slightly nicer one on Valencia at 17th. They're always friendly, my food comes quick and the Early Bird Special is a good fucking deal!

The Mangoten roll and spider rolls are two of my favorite. I tend to steer clear of anything involving dairy in my asian cuisine (never quite figured out the whole mayo-in-the-maki craze), and aside from a Philadelphia roll and something else on the menu I can't remember they comply.

It's a great place to call ahead and get an order to take home. Their sashimi is well priced and I'm never afraid to eat it.

How does that warrant 4 stars you ask? For someone who's busy and likes a quick takeout meal after work, We-Be Sushi in six years has never let me down. It's the only place I know I can spend $10 at  sushi joint and feel full and leave without getting food poisoning. It's a nice break from all the burrito joints in that neck of the woods. Maybe you'll think my standards are low, but I've got nothing but love for this sushi joint.
author: Patrice S.

description: OK, so there's some confusion here.....there are 2 We be Sushi places on Valencia...one near 22nd and the other near 16th. The food is great, but it's tiny and the last visit I had there, they were a "cash only" place. The sushi is good, but try the one near 16th....they take credit cards, have a very friendly staff and it's spacious :-)
author: Amir J.

description:
This place is garbage. the only good thing about it is the sparkling clean bathroom, it's probably never used cuz this place is whack!
The sushi was salty, the miso wasn't even miso, the tempura was bland and I wasn't even offered any green tea. The service was slow, the waitress was MIA, and the other guy helping wasn't doing that great of a job either. We weren't even given plates, even after our food came. Don't go here, maybe try Yo Yo sushi across the street if you are in this area. 
TOTAL GARBAGE!!!!
author: Full T.

description: We be sushi? Always a good value, always good qualtity. The service is good. Nothing exotic here, but I always leave happy and well-fed.
author: Paul R.

description: For the price you pay, I thought it was pretty good and fresh.  That's all there needs to be said.  Oh and the toro was pretty fresh and tasty.
author: Chaz N.

description:
The sushi is pretty good and I'm really glad that they have lemon on top of the 49er roll.  Some sushi places forget to top it off with the most important ingredient!  

Most importantly, this place is open on Sundays before 5pm which other Sushi joints aren't.  This is high on my priority list especially if I'm craving sushi.. umm.. like right now!
author: Melissa M.

description:
I'm currently broke. Ok, so I'm just trying to save money for a 2 week trip to Italy I'm taking in September. Recent Italian-ophile behavior aside, I've been fiending sushi. And like I said, I'm broke. So I asked around the office, "sushi, with one condition-- cheap AND good, not either/or, please." I was repeatedly pointed in the direction of We Be Sushi. 

The place is small, as in like 9 tables, and in a hip-but-still-pretty-shady section of the Mission. Two words to describe my overall experience-- pleasantly suprised. The service was great, the selection was pretty sushi joint standard (with some interesting exceptions) and the fish was mmm mmm fresh. 

Wasn't hot on the salmon-dill-sake marinated roll I ordered, since the dill overpowered the fish. And the spicy creamy crab roll was pretty much just a California roll, but spicy. But oh to be redeemed by the himachi, raw fish of the Japanese gods. Creamy, light and lemony. Goodness. Note to self, note to Yelpers: come back and order lots of sashimi and nigri, skip the rolls.

As we were exiting the restaurant, a couple walked by us and looked up at the We Be Sushi sign, with it's 7-UP logo and fading letters. "Looks cheesy," the girl commented. "Totally," the guy replied. How they will never know. Cheap AND good really does exist when it comes to sushi in the city.
author: Meredith O.

description: Cozy! I love the atmosphere in this little sushi joint. The sushi isn't the best you'll find in the city, but it's cheeeeeeaaapp and quite tasty for the price. Cash only.
author: Dina G.

description:
I guess everyone else Yelping here is is totally freakin' rich or something ... because IMHO We Be ROCKS!

Lunch special includes miso soup, rice, California roll w/real crab (not krab) and 4 pieces of nigiri for what? like $6.95?

and the early bird Dinner Special: miso soup, seaweed salad, some other maki roll, a mess of nigiri (any kind you want! that's right! go for 5 pieces of hamachi or tobiko or anything you want, pal) ... for under $10?

It's simple, fresh, with a bottomless cup of hot green tea

Actually, all you folks hatin' on We Be -- awesome! GO ELSEWHERE, PUH-LEEZE!!! There are not enough tables as it is ...
author: Emily D.

description:
Inexpensive, above average sushi with good ambiance.

I went her with my friend after bipassing some of the more fou-fou places on Valencia. I liked the look of this place. The decor wasn't overly trendy and was quite different from most sushi places. It's a small restaurant, but I liked that. The wait staff were very pleasant and efficient.

We split 3 rolls: the rock & roll (average to above average), a spicy tuna (which was really good), and something else that I forget, but was also quite good.

It's not the best tasting sushi that I've had, but it's inexpensive. We had these 3 rolls (6 pieces for each roll) plus a jar of sake for $17. I think that's near unbeatable for decent sushi, but I'm not as expert as other reviewers. 

But the reason that they definitely get 4 stars is their bathroom. Spotless! I'm not much of a food connaisseur, but I know my public wash rooms. This one is tops for SF.
author: J S.

description:
Can I please say, (ahem), that the cheap sushi on the west coast is leaving much to be desired.  In NYC I had an amazingly cheap and decently fresh place down the block, in SF I have We Be Sushi.

Not so fresh, not so tasty, not going to head back anytime soon.  

Oh  Fujiya, now I understand your allure, thanks for all the good times.

----------------------------

Update, after a second try I found the wait staff to be kind and the food to be cheap & passable.  I admit I was too quick to judge, and I will allow myself to be talked into more cheap webe sushi.
author: Krissy M.

description: Used scoutmob and received 50% off -- the rolls were amazing -- highly recommend the rok n roll fried -- I know I sound like a fat boy but its a nice treat :-)  Our waitress was awesome and on top of everything.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Between 2 - 3 stars

The sushi is cheap and you get what you pay for.  The fish was decent enough.  The sake nigiri was good but I couldn't finish my hamachi (it was tasted off and was too chewy)  The roll was decent and the price is right.

It's in my neighborhood so I'll go back if i'm short on cash and need my sushi fix.  If money is no object Kiji is definitely a better bet.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/kiji-japanese-restaurant-and-sushi-bar-san-francisco#hrid:9lLLgwmW29k4lMAacoRzeg
author: Shayna N.

description: I have had sushi here several times and I have always had a good experience. Table service is good and responsive.  Had the Sushi Platter #1 last night with 4 friends and we barely conquered it (none of us are sushi lightweights ;)  Good place to meet up with friends and enjoy the Mission. (see my pic of the Platter).
author: Kevin T.

description: I went on a Sunday night. I ordered a spicy tuna hand roll and a salmon hand roll. Both were sub-par, and the salmon hand roll was inedible. But I did appreciate the complimentary hot green tea and miso soup. The wait staff was pleasant and efficient. I won't be eating here again, but it seems that I am a sushi snob because the past several places I've eaten sushi I've been disappointed. I've heard others say they really enjoyed this place though.
author: Jessica R.

description: I'm not a sushi expert, so I probably shouldn't be allowed to give this place five stars, but I really LOVED this place. This was the first sushi I ever experienced and I thought it was ridiculously delicious. I think it's a little pricey, but it was really tasty sushi, and all the places I've eaten sushi at since haven't really compared, so...four stars it is.
author: Krystle B.

description: It's cash only and the sushi seems to be a little warmer than room temperature.  I have been to both locations on Valencia and experienced the same at each.  It's really inexpensive but just can't ever go back for fear of getting sick - just not worth it.
author: K W.

description:
I love the name of this place! The place is tiny, homey, and cheap! It is wonderfully close to my house, so whenever I'm craving sushi (which is a lot) it's super easy to just go down the street. There is usually not a long wait, the longest was maybe 10 mins on a Friday night? And the food comes out relatively fast. The waitresses are helpful and sweet and so is that little old sushi man in the back. 
The sushi itself isn't your gourmet, freshly caught from the water kind of fish, but it's still pretty tasty to me. They have a good selection of special rolls and I always leave full and satisfied. Last night I went and spent $28 (incl. tip) for 3 special rolls and 3 nigiri orders. Sweet deal!
author: Pet O.

description:
I've been coming here for 20 years, often weekly. It's a small neighborhood place, with reliably good, cheap sushi, essential for thrifty sushi addicts. 

Nowadays, I always go for the earlybird special (5-7pm)... where I can choose ANY 5 nigiri, a roll (I substitute a California extra $1), seaweed salad, & miso soup, plus a bowl of rice.  Me and the hubby get out of here for $25, including a coke, and a tip - and these days, that's only slightly more than burritos!  Jesus H.

The beer and sake are fine here. The rolls are good too. Dang I've had almost everything on the menu, it's all good. I really enjoy the Shiro Maguro sashimi with ponzu sauce.

This is a great place to come if you are on your way to a movie, or to one of the neighborhood bars or clubs. It's not a "impress your date" place. It's a "I gotta eat some sushi even though I had it two days ago" place.

Webe sushi trivia - they used to be called "McSushi." A loooong time ago. Then McDonald's got POd. So they had a renaming contest. "WeBe" won.
author: Dusty R.

description:
When this place is on, it's really good! Lots of choices, good sake list, one really nice waitress who's super helpful (Forgot her name).
Reasonably priced and a nice, basic place to go for sushi.
author: Mark S.

description: When I lived in the Mission a few years ago, this place was always the fall back if the line at Puerto Allegre was too long.  Good to see that not a lot has changed since I moved away 5+ years ago.  I was in SF for a 24 hour period and was itching for some margs and good Mexican so we strolled down to Valencia.  As expected, at 9PM on a Wed night, the line for Puerto Allegre was long.  We opted for this place almost by default.  The service is good, I was happy that our waitress spoke Japanese and the food was fine.  I was famished from my travels so this plus a few bottles of Asahi and saki went down great.
author: Joe O.

description:
2 stars for the sushi, but I love it for the cheapness and cuteness. I always go there for the early-bird special, and prefer the seaweed salad to the spinach salad. They provide complimentary tea upon request. The miso soup is pretty good, too. Far from top-notch quality, but I always leave feeling very full and satisfied for about $10.
Also, I feel very comfortable eating here alone and used to do so regularly before taking a class at the nearby City College campus. It's good for that, or for pairs. They also accommodate groups of up to 6 people.
author: Kate A.

description: Sushi is average, but this is my go-to-place in the mission for delivery.  Quick and reasonable prices.
author: Manoj L.

description:
For $12.95, you get a "Dinner Special" sushi combination with 7 nigiris and two low-end rolls (California and sweet-eggplant) and a bowl of miso soup.  It's as cheap as it gets for sushi in San Francisco (or just about anywhere in US for that matter). 

Let's be reasonable now -- you can't expect the best-in-town level sushi at this price (both in terms of freshness of ingredients or in the quality of preparation), but what you do get is better than what I expected at the price; the fish portions are generously cut, and the preparation is solid.

Besides the favorable quality-to-price ratio, the atmosphere is also something to note.  This is a tiny place with seating for 20-30, but it's not necessarily a bare-bones hole-in-the-wall; this location has a grungy-artsy decor with oversized Japanese print banners and random relics and deocrations -- an overall fun atmosphere in my book, but some might prefer the sedated and clean mood of the location just several blocks down Valencia (this location also has a few more items on the menu, such as chirashi).  There's also no sushi-bar here (you know, the refrigerated glass case, bar seating, row of sushi chefs, etc.) -- the food is prepared around what looks like a small buffet table.  It's a casual place.

I found the place in a San Francisco guide book (one of those titles that promises to reveal the 'untouristy' side of SF), and I've taken the BART from my hotel in Union Square to 16th/Mission, then walked 20 minutes to get here (I'm a bit of a foodie).  All in all, I'd recommend this place if you find yourself in the neighborhood, craving sushi in a laid-back but fun atmosphere -- but it's probably not worth the trek that I made.
author: choong l.

description:
WE BE CHEAP!!!

This is perfectly alright sushi for the $.  Friendly staff, ok fish, not bad miso soup and spinach salads....

I say it is a-ok.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I had to review this place, I eat here about every other week.  

This place is small, but has a lot of character.  I am not a big sushi person, but I enjoy it because its a light and fresh meal.

I have never had a problem with the fish I have eaten here.  Also, the rolls are a little thin, but at least they hold up when you're dunking them in soy sauce.  

If you are looking for a cool place to enjoy some sushi that's not too pricey, I would definitely check out this spot.
author: Jaime T.

description: I wish I had an iPhone app that as I walked into We Be Sushi, beeped at me and rang a loud fire alarm. This place, quite simply, is some of the most revolting and disgusting food I have ever eaten, and I am not a picky eater. I live next door and so I have eaten there many times, since its convenient and I like sushi. Tonight was the last straw. The seaweed was rotten, the roll inedible, the nigiri tasted and looked like it had been sitting outside for days. The only thing I could really stomach was the free soup. I keep forgetting that its so bad, like some kind of food amnesia and keep going back. But I think now that I've taken the time to write this review I will indeed never eat there again. Going to go puke now.
author: Ish H.

description:
When all you need is non-greasy food in the Mission, you can be harder pressed than you may realize. When was the last meal you ate out in the Mission that didn't involve lots of sauce, fat, cream, or an obscene carb binge?

When the winter and flu blues got ya down, there's nothing like a miso soup and green tea from the likes of We Be to lift your spirits. The steadily narrowing walls envelop you and the neon reflects in your co-diner's glasses. (You do only eat out with people with glasses, right, Hipster?)

For this price, rolls and sushi seem to have somewhat of a glass ceiling in this town, and while We Be does relative justice to the art, they are not exempt to the rule.

Considering there aren't many options for the price and in the area, it's worth a drop-by.
author: Blake E.

description:
Hm..... Don't know why people are hatin' on this place - you really get what you pay for, so don't expect the world of this tiny homestyle establishment.

I love the variety of rolls (maki) that make it so easy to share with a friend. It's easier to get a big order to split, since the tables are tiny with not enough room for the water, tea, sake, soup AND sushi.

I really enjoy coming here for a quick snack. And there is convenient parking in the garage around the corner which also isn't terribly expensive. Reminds me of Shino Express Sushi in Boston, which is one of my favorite places.

Friendly, homemade, cozy atmosphere with parking. One of my favorite SF places!
author: dj z.

description:
It was ok. Didn't like the miso soup, which is a make or break for my sushi experience. They put onions in it....

I want to like this place because the waitress lady was sooo sweet. I'm hoping to find a better sushi restaurant soon because I need a fix.

I guess I can only see myself going back in an emergency. But that seems unlikely given there are several other places nearby. You get the idea...
author: Maryanne R.

description:
We Be Sushi aka We Be A Mediocre Experience

My dining partner and I thought we would head out to dinner a little early on Friday night to avoid a long line - we had been wanting to try We Be Sushi and had noticed the *very* small dining space the few times that we had passed by.  I was pleased at the 15 minute wait, which was about 15 minutes.  Usually you go somewhere and 15 minutes can mean 30 depending on the restaurant and the night.

Unfortunately, since there was a man sitting in front of the menu most of the time we were waiting outside, we failed to see the "CASH ONLY" sign until 2 minutes before we were seated.  So, I was seated while my partner made a mad dash to the ATM.  That sign REALLY needs to be bigger.

Inside, I noticed that there were quite a few tables that were placed only a few inches away from each other because of the size of the restaurant - and I was immediately seated next to a young boy and what looked like his mother.  He was talking loudly on his cell phone, so I was lucky when I was able to move to a table on the opposite wall where there wasn't another table two inches from me!

Anyway, my dining partner returned and we ordered small beers.  He ordered tuna and I ordered the chicken dinner.  He said that his tuna tasted like it had been swimming in the holding tank too long and that it was still a little frozen in the middle - even though it should have been served at room temperature.  As for my dinner, I liked my miso soup and I really enjoyed the rice.  The chicken was a little crispy on the outside but really tender.  There was a large portion of salad that had a tangy citrus dressing that was tasty.  My partner and I were able to share my dinner with only a little salad left over.

There were GOOD elements to our dinner: like the cold beer, wall decorations, and my chicken dinner.

Things I would PASS on again if I had the chance:  the restaurant being so small, the sushi, and their cash only policy.
author: Heather S.

description: I kind of gag after I thought what I had eaten at this place. To start, the edemame was served with a hefty amount of salt on one part of the bowl so that some edamame were extremely salty. Second, the house salad was rather too large for me, although good in taste, not what I was looking for in an appetizer ($5). The California roll is what grossed me out. The inside part, which is supposed to be imitation crab, seemed to be dry flaky pieces of something that resembled something like imitation-imitation crab. I couldn't eat more than 2 pieces. The spider roll was rather dry and was missing some type of sauce that should be drizzled on top. In an effort to not see wasted food and money, I took my leftovers home, only to trash them later that night. Sorry we be sushi but I gotta keep it real!
author: Den M.

description: Randomly decided to go to We Be with my friend last night as we were walking down Valencia. The place is close to home. Good chicken teriyaki! Lots of delicious sake too. And chill waitstaff. I made friends with my server Saiman and he is a cool dude. I'll come back to this place.
author: J L.

description:
Cheap, yes.  Crap, no.  I like it here.  It's actually pretty fresh IMHO and I eat a TON of sushi (sometimes almost every day at some points during my life).  But I suppose it could depend on what you order, I stick with nigiri.  The only thing I didn't like is this time I went, they put dill on my sake nigiri (are they trying to americanize it?!...personally didn't like).

I go to both this location (at 22nd) and the other down the street near 16th.  It's generally easier to park at this one though both locations are next to cheap muni lots.  I think I like this one better though it's a bit more hole in the wall and half the size (and I think I got sick once from the Valencia @ 16th one, but I still go there anyway).  

And it's run by Asian people!  C'mon how bad can sushi be if it's run by real Asian people.
author: Chris P.

description:
This is a very kewl neighborhood type place where you get to know the staff....who have always been GREAT. The sushi is good, not GREAT, but good....and for the price of dinner you cant go wrong. 

This place actually reminds me of a few places in Japan where I ate. It's small, but very homey!!!! For the people who said this place is terrible......That's kewl!!! Please don't come back....lol
author: Troy H.

description:
All I get here are basic rolls - I don't go for the "freshest sushi" - but yeah, McSushi that doesn't suck, but is great on a budget or "everyday" sushi-eating.

I love eating here right after a long soak and steam at Osento.
author: Kali D.

description:
I love their sign...Sushi Like Mom Used to Make.

that's about it though

it was loud...I mean VERY loud because of some frat dork and sorostitutes behind us chanting on and on about some lame 21 year old drinking games.  Time and place people, and in a Sushi place like Mom used to make...not so appropriate.  It was really just lame and loud...kinda pissed me off.  Then, the power went out.  Ever eat sushi in the dark?  We did.  Oh, and ever try to pay with a credit card when there isn't any power?  We couldn't...which made our large group dinner very interesting.

overall...food was fine...nothing special...but not bad.
author: Matt V.

description:
Came to WeBe before a night out in the Mission.  I had fond memories of their Geary shop before they closed it down.  I remember them as cheap, simple, and pretty good.  This experience kind of wrecked all those memories.  First, the venue - I can understand it's in the mission, but it looked like a dirty cafeteria, and sitting in the back where I could see the sushi prep, it didn't look all that sanitary.  It's still cheap - in fact, I think it's cheaper than the one I used to frequent, but I don't think it was very fresh as I had a fishy taste in my mouth the rest of the evening.

I ordered a sushi dinner combo - the nigiri that came out were not what was listed on the menu for whatever reason, and I think they shortchanged me on a piece.  Also, the shittake roll was pretty gross, I think I tasted cream cheese in there - some ppl like it in rolls, but I'm not a fan.  My amaebi, while really cheap, did not come with the fried heads.  Now that I think of it, I guess I feel lucky that the uni we ordered was not spoiled.

The servers are nice, and WeBe really is cheap, but with so many sushi options out there, you can find better, even at this price.  And just to be clear, CASH ONLY.
author: Jim W.

description:
Steve and I come here if we are craving for quick japanese food. Dont expect a lot, again it serves its purpose. Quick Decent Sushi Bites.

This I have learned if you want really good Sushi or Japanese Restaurants for that matter, you have to go to restaurants that has the Chef as the Restaurant name or a place that means beach...Yeah Sushi Rock doesnt cut it, not that I am saying their not good.
author: Malou C.

description:
no bad not bad. the name makes you feel like this place is a cheap bad sushi joint. i tried it, it's not!

it's more like a cheap okay sushi joint.
author: Ameer N.

description:
The sushi was definitely cheap, but the quality was just ok.  Of course, it's hard to fine cheap excellent sushi.  It's ok for take out and maybe fast eating but if you want quality of fresh fish than this place is not it.  However, for $5 uni...it was quite good.  

I didn't like the fact that we can't order Udon to go though.  The chef didn't want to make it.  We really want to eat udon that night so we were a bit disappointed.

The wait is definitely long, especially for take out.
author: Suzn L.

description: Just had dinner there and I  did not recognize any of the staff. I waited at least 45 minutes for 3 rolls that I ordered. The Salmon was chewy and fatty and I was afraid to continue eating. After I heard other patrons saying that there were new owners i definitely knew that this place had gone downhill. Too bad as it was always a good place to eat sushi at a decent price in SF.
author: Sal V.

description: Not much to look at, but the sushi is fantastic and the service attentive all at very reasonable prices.  Great value for what you pay for so who cares if the interior looks like the rest of Mission?
author: Blake B.

description:
This is definitely not a swank supernice sit down joint, but if you want to grab a quick bite of simple sushi, it's a great place to go. Not the place for fancy towering sushi concoctions... The rolls are smallish, so order ~3 for a decent size meal. Most of them are $3-4, so it's super affordable.

Oddly, just recently they started using random corporate mugs instead of the Japanese-looking ones they usually had, and the free appetizer is carrot sticks in a cup, which is kind of hilariously lame, but for the price we're not complaining.

The waitresses aren't chatty or anything, but they respond to questions in a friendly manner and let us know that there was fish-stock in the miso soup after noticing that my boyfriend had ordered all vegetarian items. They've got a nice variety of vegetarian items, which is not exactly easy to find, having looked at other sushi joints in the city. I love the avocado rolls!
author: Jin Z.

description:
we be chicken dish....don't order it!!  Too dry and over cooked!!!

Spinach salad....don't order it!!!   Very chewy and tough unless u want to pretend it's gum and it's not double mint... More like mop fibers and gets all in ur teeth. 

Cheap yes. Quick yes. Great no. It's ok and I still will go there for the sushi rolls.
author: Jay S.

description: If this review were solely about quality, I would knock off a star. I've had better sushi elsewhere but I've never had cheaper sushi ANYWHERE. Including safeway. For the price this place is great, I'm a huge fan of spicy tuna rolls and this place has them for under four bucks, and they taste great! The place is small though, I wouldn't recommend coming here with more than four people total.
author: Matt F.

description: Good place where you can have a light lunch for 15$. The kitchen is the table area.. you can see what you are goin' to eat! Small place, nice smiles!
author: Florentin H.

description:
I think this place deserves better reviews than it's getting.  For the price, it's reliably good sushi.  And the miso might be my favorite in the city.

It's not a place to take out-of-towners that you want to impress (for that I recommend Eiji) but if you're a mission local then this place is exactly what you want 2 blocks from your apartment: cheap and good and easy to get a table if you know when to go (i.e early).

i don't know what it is, but i love the atmosphere here: it's a true hole-in-the wall, warm and narrow inside, wooden tables and chairs, it feels well-worn and comfortable.  It's a great place to catch up with an old friend (maybe not an old flame as one reviewer noted) or by yourself. A perfect neighborhood sushi spot.

(please note: this review is of the one near 22nd street - I think some of the reviewers have been confusing it with the one near 16th - the 22nd street location has much better food, service, and atmosphere.)
author: Zachary L.

description:
The  Yuppie Hordes waiting in line at Tokyo Go-Go can call me a philistine, but when I want to simply chow down on inexpensive fresh sushi and interesting rolls, I'm going to We Be. 

I think it's interesting that Tokyo GG and Blowfish had the same average rating as We Be.  It goes to show that good quality and an unpretentious scene can keep a place in business for a long time, even if it's not trendy.  I'd like to see the trendy places in 5 years.  Will they still be there?

But cheese of any kind on Sushi is NOT Kosher!
author: raven n.

description:
Update 04-08: 

I still believe it's a good deal for the money, but there have been a couple of times lately were the fish was not as fresh as it could have been. Their Miso soup is still always great though. 


It's a solid 3 stars for me, but definitely not 4 stars anymore as before.

So I actually do like this place! The sushi is pretty decent for not so much money. I usually get take-out, so I can't really comment on the service. But they are friendly enough when they hand me the bag.
author: Nucnuc M.

description:
Not super fancy at all.  There's a white lady and a filipino lady working there, which is different for a japanese place, but there are japanese people there (we don't like those chinese owned jap restaurants).  But it is cheap and pretty good, especially for veggies.  They have more than just avocado rolls, kna-mean!  Oooh, and Stephie thinks they have the best Ume (plum) maki in the city.  She's tried them in other restaurants, and they're just not as good.  The fish didn't look like the best of the best, but Stephie's pretty sure noone's dying. 

Mikey ordered a not-so-large large sapporo, and they charged him $6 for it. An outrage!
author: Steph and Mike A.

description:
I go here because it is cheap and close.
You should only go here because it is cheap and close.
I will say the staff is nice and friendly, but if you came here for the sushi, you might as well just go get pre packaged sushi from the supermarket.
