The food is heavier than I believe sushi is suppose to be and there is nothing very special about this place other than the fact that is is clean and intimate.
author: Janel M.

description:
Just ate lunch here.  I had the #8 saba (mackerel) lunch and a cucumber salad as an appetizer.  

This is the best mackerel I ever had in the city.  If you're as big a fan as I am of tasty cooked mackerel, We Be Sushi is the place to go!  

Not only did they offer generous portions of miso, rice, the fish itself, the cucumber salad and the salad that came with the fish, but they were all cooked/prepared superbly.  The mackerel was had a light, buttery taste without the over-fishiness that often comes with mackerel.  It wasn't over-cooked to the point where you see charred/hard edges and the meat was fluffy.  All this means is that the fish was FRESH and cooked by an experienced cook who takes pride in their food.  The two salads were fresh and tasty as well.  All in all, absolutely frabjous.  All for only $15, which included a $3 tip.  

I am so full right now, and I couldn't even finish the cucumber salad or the rice.  We Be Sushi is the real deal with unexpected generous portions.
author: Chris C.

description: Solid for it's affordable prices. Not the best sushi, but an easy go-to.
author: Kat L.

description: I like We Be, I've been a fan for years.  It's cheap and darn tasty.  Try the tuna with ponzu sauce, it's one of my favorites.  Okay, it's not fanciest place to have sushi but again, it's consistently great food and should not be overlooked.
author: Keith B.

description: They have creative sushi options, complimentary soup, and it's super cute. My favorite tiny restaurant in the city.
author: Cynthia J.

description: If I were just rating on the final 10 minutes of my experience I would have given the place a 4. And I admit that my review might be skewed because we sat down about 45 minutes before close, but the service was average at best and so was the sushi. We asked for water and didn't see a server again for nearly 20 minutes and never got the extra ginger we requested when we finally got our water. Literally, we sat there with twi final pieces of sushi each waiting for a little ginger to compliment the bland meal until we finally gave up. Alas, I would not recommend this place nor would I return.
author: Greg G.

description: It's fairly inexpensive sushi thats OK. The foods not the best, but is by no means bad, especially when you look at the price. This site is pretty small so don't expect to get a table for more then four people and even then you may have to wait a bit because it can get busy.
author: Tony S.

description: So this place is not getting a lot of love...but the sushi is so cheap AND it tastes good.  It's not super high quality and they don't have any fancy rolls, but a delicious tempura prawn roll is only $4!  Their nigiri is good and they have great aparagus and eggplant maki.  If you want sushi and you dont want to spend a lot, I dont see how you can go wrong.  The waitresses are kind of Zen gone bad, in the sense that they are moving at a slooooooooow pace, but deal if you want cheap sushi.
author: Stacy R.

description: Cheap. Funky. Tasty. Not too much rice in the rolls. I'm a fan :)
author: Leslie F.

description: You gotta love this place, it's about as cozy as an armpit and about the same size, about as cheap and as welcoming as a capp street hoe and as yummy as both. All around my kind of place. Don't come here if you're in a hurry on a Friday night , looking for fine dining experience or  claustrophobic but if you're broke, hungry  and a lover of sushi  this place will more than do the trick.
author: Emma G.

description: Should be more like "We Be Sucky." This place blows the fat one. I'd sooner eat a brown bruised up bannana that fell off one of the many fruit stands on Valencia and landed on top of the gutter.
author: Stacy T.

description: This place is my favorite type of restaurant; maybe a little on the small size, but quality food, friendly staff and low prices.  Good neighborhood joint for sure!  I actually am ashamed at how often I go there as my attendance seems to be the result of an addiction to their rolls, Udon and tempura.
author: gavbo O.

description:
i like this rest somehow. the owner is japanese ( that is comforting to know!) the service can be little slow if they are busy. but the price is rather cheap if i compared with other rest. they do have the quality and innovative menu. love the salad dressing and the salmon miso marinated. 
i recommend this rest to my japanese friends, and they loved it ! yay..
author: sherly A.

description:
i've had better sushi. 

but i had to empty out my piggy bank, overdraw the water in the wells account, and owe my date more tuna back at the house. sooo....

we be sushi makes me be happy. 

its like eating over at your pyscho japam buddy's parent's house. hilarious, strangely americanized, basically delicious, and well, almost free.

so if you stick to simple basics - (its your fault for ordering chicken/or parmesean cheese at a sushi joint) - like the maki, all under $3.50 for 6 pieces, you can have a selection of salmon with avocado, rock and roll unagi, tempura shrimp, spicy tuna and lots of vege rolls, and still have extra cash in your pocket to splurge on that new import ep at aquarius records next door. 

and for that we be thankful.
author: diana m.

description:
No.

Worse than Grocery Store sushi.  You have to actually work hard to outfail grocery store sushi.

Tiny, sad little rolls that taste like the intersection of diced goldfish and failure.

Save yourself!  Move right along to...  I don't even care.  Go to Taco Bell, they at least have their culinary expectations set utterly appropriately.  Do not subject your palate to this unless you're trying to atone for something heavy.
author: josh s.

description: It's biggest advantage is that you can get yourself full of sushi for only about $20-30, which is a great deal. The sushi, however, certainly isn't the greatest, freshest, or most flavorful. It's not actively bad, mind you, but it's certainly not fantastic either. But it is cheap.
author: Don H.

description:
not sure what the sushi scene is like in the mission given that i'm not a mission neighborhood native or anything, but bf and i stumbled across this place during a walk around the block NYE weekend and it was fully sufficient and adequately standard as far as our sushi-tastes go (and i'd have to say, we are bit of sushi snobs).  

to say that it was the best rolls i've ever had would be a huge over-statement, but it was still decent for the price...(speaking of which, IT'S CASH ONLY!!!)

i enjoyed the atmosphere -- cozy and casual -- and the service was friendly and comfortable.

and that's really all i have to say about that!
author: Grace O.

description: This place is just such a great little chill fun crazy spot to gobble up some good and cheap and fresh and tasty sushi.  Everything is always yummy and although some things are better than others I am always completely satisfied for my quick sushi craving and have a blast here most of all.  For the mix of the food, the scene, the price, it's hard to beat.
author: Today Y.

description: Very uninspired sushi , but they are saved by the dinner special where you can have seaweed salad, miso & a few uninspired rolls for under 10 dollars a person. Of course, you have to eat it before 7.30 or some other senior citizen hour, but that only means you have more time and money to drink at Lone Palm, Doc's Clock or Mission Bar. For some reason, they are always playing the Dirty Dancing soundtrack which was cute at first but then just got irritating. I prefer this location to the one up on 16th solely due to the schizophrenic decorating. All in all, 3 stars.
author: Maria D.

description: mmmmmmm, I see this place packed during dinner, and I just don't get it. I think we only went here because yoyo's was closed... not that yoyo's is a 5 star place, but I found We Be Sushi well below the standards of Yoyo's.
author: danny e.

description: Came back for the early bird and sat around for fifteen to twenty minutes with no water or even a "Hello" from the waitress, maybe they should have kept their trustworthy servers instead of hiring teenagers. It's too bad, because WeBe was one of my favorite spots for cheap Japanese food. Also, the incredibly loud dude sitting next to us discussing his sex life was not a  welcome addition to a small place (not that I blame them for that).
author: Jesse S.

description: This place doesn't have any high chairs, tiny and only takes cash.  Even the local dive by my house has a high chair!
author: Jo B.

description: So we were doing our laundry around the corner from here and we got hungry, so we tried it.  Smells like fish in there and not necessarily in a good way (is there a good way?).  We got a bunch of various rolls and one of them tasted ok, but the rest were pretty bad and One was so nasty we didn't even eat it.  We've had some pretty shitty sushi before, but rarely do both of us not even touch one whole roll.  I think it was straight up Chicken of the Sea.  And as embarrassing as it is to admit this, I feel compelled to announce that I had to take an emergency shit at the Walgreens shortly afterward.  That star is for the sign, and the name.    Of course I should have known you'll get what you ask for when you eat at a place called We Be Sushi.
author: Urwhatuea T.

description: The most exciting part of We Be occurred while i was waiting outside while my friend paid for our takeout inside; I looked up and a rain drop fell directly into my right eye.  I reeled around, straining to keep my grip on a 12 pack of red stripe as I wondered whether the water would turn me into a flesh eating zombie like when the blood fell into the guy's eye in 28 Days Later.  Then my friend came out, and we later ate some average sushi at a decent price.
author: Mr. G.

description: this is our go to place for sushi in valencia, we really love it because it's so laid back and is walking distant from my bf's place.  Prices are decent and the fish is fresh and the staff are friendly.
author: Tara B.

description: Awesome place! Four of us got sushi, sake and sopporos for  $76. The restaurant is really small but it was clean, service was quick, cheap and good for the price.  I would go back.
author: Na N.

description:
By far one my my favorite sushi spots in the city...

We always order sushi... never had the cooked food. 

We order Hamachi Sashimi as if it were the only thing on the menu. Their hamachi is so fresh and tasty. I've been to other places and nothing compares to We Be Sushi's

I Loved their 275 roll.... that is until they removed it from the menu. The 275 roll costs $2.75 and it consisted in fish with parmesean cheese in a sushi roll. Never new something this simple can taste soooo good!!

Can't go wrong with any of their sushi....

Thier bottomless hot tea is a plus.... and it's free.

The only reason I removed a star is because of the soliciting mariachis that come by while you're trying to enjoy your food. Imagine sitting in a japanese restaurant having a good time and eating.... and then the next minute you're being serenaded by a member of a mariachi band who sings one song in a foreign language and comes around with a bag so you can donate money for the song he just sang that you didn't understand. Sorry.... but if I wanted to hear the mariachi band.... I would've gone to the taqueria. 

Parking can be a little tricky in this area also.
author: Emma N.

description: How can you go wrong with a Mexican guitarist in a sushi bar.  Works on so many levels!
author: Dan B.

description: The sushi is cheap pretty good for what you pay.  Small dining area pretty much merged with the kitchen.  I wouldn't come here for sashimi, but they have a pretty good variety of rolls.  We Be is a local favorite for it's excellent prices and neighborhood feel.
author: Adrian N.

description: Ate here once, didn't like anything I ate.  The nigiri was fishy and warm, the rolls were boring, the miso was too salty and the service was nothing special.  I never went back.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Nilu r.

description: I am not impressed with this place.  Im not going to say it was horrible but I think with the gazillion sushi places in the city this is not even close to being one of the best.  The service was great I'll give it that.  But the sushi menu was lacking.  When I asked if we could kind of create a roll the waitress said we could add to a roll but for the most part they are pre-rolled which I am not a fan of.  There were also onions in the Miso soup which is a downfall for me.  The fish was not the freshest but not disgusting by any means.  The spicy tuna roll is spicy which is a plus and not because it was doused in spicy sauce.  The prices were reasonable but I probably won't be back.
author: Jen C.

description:
I was seated by the front window, and after our coke had arrived, I noticed a faint odor. It smelled like someone had pissed in the corner. As the dinner went on, it seemed to get stronger. I couldn't handle the stench and had to move my chair away from the window, which didn't help too much.

The tempura wasn't bad, actually. Most places don't include mushroom in it. My bf's order of eel donburi came out way after mine. I think they had it sitting on the counter and the waitress forgot to bring it over because it arrived cold. And they forgot about my california rolls. We didn't bother complaining, since the rolls that came with the eel tasted old and crusty. We wanted to pay and get out of that place A.S.A.P. away from the stink.
author: Starla L.

description: After a long day at Stern Grove....a wait at Dosa...myself and 2 friends went to have some dinner. I've never been here before, but my friends have. Apparently the lunch specials are dirt cheap. I enjoyed my vegetarian special. I really liked the seaweed salad. It was a bummer that there was no dessert. Quaint and delic.
author: Anita C.

description: Unpretentious, just good ol' raw fish. The rolls are tasty, but not very exciting compared to other places (liek Sushi Bistro!) and are also on the smaller side with a lot of rice. Crazy cheap lunch specials, inlcude miso soup, 4 pieces nigiri and a roll for $6.95.
author: Yodel A.

description: Good for maki rolls and tempura, not so great for fresh fish. We were very happy with our Dragon Roll, eggplant roll, tempura, and unagi nigiri. The sashimi definitely left a lot to be desired. Service, ambience and price were all good. I'd definitely come back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Joe R.

description: Good but not amazing sushi, indifferent service, cheap and tacky ambience. Good hole-in-the-wall sushi with friends. Not a good date venue.
author: Laurie V.

description: They fixed it!  I don't what they did, but this place is back up to snuff!  I'm so happy to have my sushi place back again.  Good job WeBe, now don't mess it up!
author: C H.

description: I LOVED this place my first time, on a weekend night with Japanese sushi chefs.  The second time on a weeknight, it was just alright, nothing special.  I noted that there were non-Japanese sushi chefs....hmmmm, I'll need to try it again.  Good service both times, though.
author: Ravi C.

description:
gross.  sushi served in the mission.  not ideal.  
"missionsushi" = oxymoron.

however, walking across the street to Casanova might help drown your rotten raw fish sorrows away.
author: Kelsey C.

description: Yummy sushi in my tummy. I love this place. Inexpensive and delicious. Sometimes it can be a bit crowded and the bathroom is in a bit of an inconvient spot but dinner for 4 for $40. I think there must have been a mistake. Maybe we weren't charged for our sake. I don't know but we all left full and delirious with joy. The service is good but if it is busy sometimes the food takes a little longer than a minute. More time for Sake I say. After going there I was chanting WE BE SUSHI for days.
author: Eryn L.

description: You get what you pay for. Yes, it's uninspired and yes, it's not the freshest fish in the city and yes, they serve tea in old, white corporate mugs, but...the eats are cheap! For a table of five, we each ate for $15, and I really can't say the last time I ate sushi and was full for that cheap.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: ICK ICK ICK... just don't go this place has nothing to offer!!! Both food and service were terrible.
author: Martha M.

description: Great cheap sushi, the shitake and portabello rolls were the best in our order.  The shrimp roll wasn't that good and the california maki was okay.  Great for reliable sushi with friends.  Not alot of seating, we were lucky there was a table so wasn't much of a wait, but I could see it possible.
author: Asha H.

description: Stingy portions, nasty service. But it's cheap and won't kill you, so there's that.
author: Amy K.

description: The 7Up sign is doing them no favors but I really have grown a fondness of this place. Do not take your sushi snob friends here, this is just-ok sushi but no matter! It's affordable, tasty and will do the trick. The staff is so nice. You basically trot into their kitchen to give them a carryout order. When you leave, the servers say goodbye to you like you are a regular.
author: Mission S.

description:
That was THE best miso soup I ever had.
Umm it was really Americanized....
Like, it had noodles and stuff in it.

$10 and I was stuffed: 6 pieces of nigiri sushi and 6 pieces of CA rolls, soup and rice. Yum!

Of course I have to comment on the bathroom and let me just say:
it's large, 
clean, 
has nice tiles on the floor 
and is totally worth an extra half star.

Minus one star for tough seaweed and pushy waitress.
author: A W.

description: Small place with lots of flavor! I should warn you all that I'm not the *biggest* seafood fan, so my review is somewhat limited... but the chicken teriyaki meal was really yummy. The miso soup here is beyond delicious... Some of the best I've had. My boyfriend & our friend shared the dragon roll, which apparently was some of the best sushi they've had. We had a pretty good experience -- a great and affordable "dive" sushi bar!
author: Rebecca F.

description: Good old redoubtable We Be. When it opened it was an annoying, slightly expensive place... now that the neighborhood has radically gentrified around them, they are a cheap, nice sushi joint. Isn't it weird how this happens? A nice, average neighborhood place...
author: Dan S.

description: An ode to mediocrity.  Really not worth any wait, and only if you are really hungry.  The wait i sustained for 4 pieces of sushi and one roll was un acceptable. and the food was much less soo
author: Spanky M.

description: We came for the well priced happy hour specials, but I got so turned off by the interior that everything that were served was tainted by that perception.  I wont go back.
author: Suzy M.

description: This was definitely not a good sushi experience. I didn't even want to go here to begin with but my boyfriend and roommate insisted. The sushi was pretty mediocre and in the middle of our meal a couple of guys came in to play guitar and sing some Mexican tunes VERY LOUDLY. I guess they were just practicing their trade, but this place is so tiny that it was appallingly awkward to continue eating while listening to the almost deafening music. I don't fault We Be Sushi for that... I guess. I fault them for poor sushi, though. Won't do this one again.
author: Lili L.

description: ...always good...always fresh...excellent service and only three blocks away...go there 3-4 times a month for years...don't understand the questionable reviews...never once had a questionable meal there...wish they'd take credit cards like the one down the street that is in my frequent diners program...
author: Bob L.

description:
This is the way sushi should be!

Been here at least 5 times now.  Inexpensive rolls and sashimi, even for what would be thought the pricey rolls and sashimi.  Miso soup with every order.  Excellent alcohol selection.  

So good for cheap!  Since when did sushi become so pricey?!  It's not a fad, it's a cuisine.
author: Kristina M.

description: Wish I could give 4.5 - while this isn't the best sushi ever, it may be one of the best deals for your dollar in the city. My fiance and I had a lot of sushi - walked away really full - plus drinks and the bill came out to only $50 - not bad!! Like I said, the sushi isn't the best ever, but I'll definitely go back for the location, friendly service, and to have a good sushi meal without breaking the bank.
author: Niki N.

description: Cute place, long wait, cheap but uninspired sushi.  Plus, they only take cash.  I'd avoid it
author: Steve S.

description: If you want some sushi quickly, DON'T GO HERE!!! Came in on my lunch break with some co-workers and lunch ended up taking over an hour!  You'd think with that amount of time, they would have figured out how to de-ice the salmon before serving it to you, but maybe they specialize in raw salmon popsicles (like otter pops but fishier)? The only thing that was good about We Be Sushi was the service, hence the two stars. Don't go for the food!! In fact, don't go here at all, there's really no reason to punish your taste buds!
author: Craig E.

description: Waitress was really friendly and the food decent.  I had the lunch special and could not finish all the food.  The miso soup is pretty good and the sushi acceptable.  The service was fast and it included tea.  You get what you pay for and for $7.50, I think I got a pretty decent lunch.
author: Brenda B.

description: My second favorite place for cheap sushi. Not the best, but it's pretty good.
author: Maricel B.

description: I didn't have a horrible experience here like some of you had; I would say it was decent. The sushi was okay, but it did remind of grocery store sushi. I really liked the miso soup - it was actually probably the best I've ever had. The tempura was really good, and the waitress was friendly and fast. I didn't have high expectations going in, so I wasn't too disappointed.
author: Ashly M.

description: I settled in here before work one Friday for a pre-work, pick-me-up, lunch of sushi and Sapphoro. I got two rolls - the eel and the asparagus. Both were very yummy. At lunch time there were a lot of people dining alone. I think it's because the prices are fairly low for such quality food. It makes splurging on sushi for lunch seem less ridiculous. I liked it.
author: Kathleen D.

description: Wow, maybe some people went here when the normal sushi chef was gone but I really liked this place.  The rolls were pretty good as were the various nigiri I tried.  It's nothing amazing but look at the price you're paying and you'll think you got a bargain.
author: Helen C.

description: A deal.  Their sushi is usually good, and fairly often one of the nigiri that I order (salmon this week, hamach the next) is really superb.  I'd recommend the fresh salmon, and the seaweed and spinach salads. Hamachi ranges from fantastic to respectable.  Spicy tuna is the big misstep here - leftover tuna shavings with too-spicy, too-gloppy sauce, and the unagi is never hot enough.   Everything else is pretty good.  Decor is fun.
author: Jordan J.

description: Not the best sushi I've ever had but still very good.  I'm no sushi expert anyways, maybe that's why I like this place.  I've tried several of their rolls and they all taste pretty good.  I love the complimentary miso soup.  There is an older Asian lady that usually works until closing who is always friendly and great at keeping those miso soup refills coming.  The place is small and cozy, and reasonable priced.
author: P D.

description: I don't have the money for $20 a plate sushi so this We Be (not the one at 16th) is the way to go for me, I always get a good meal for a reasonable price, love the seaweed salad, great philly roll, all the sashimi tastes so fresh and clean. I adore the decor and it's a good spot to have a quiet meal with a friend. If you aren't expecting sushi with hella frills and are tryin to save some dough this place is awesome. Yea and I second the emotion on great miso soup! Plus the "Early Bird" dinner special goes 5-7, perfect for post work cheap takeout on the way home from BART. Food comes fast, don't try to take a ginormous crew here it's small.
author: A S.

description:
i love this place! actually both of them - there are two on valencia.
small happy places with cheap, good sushi and miso soup full of goodies. 
the lunch special is an amazing deal and the nigori sake is really really good! 
i used to go here with a book and have a great lunch alone. 
that was when i lived happily in the mission....
author: Sole A.

description:
I've only been here once, and maybe it'll lose a star or three if I wake up booting tomorrow morning, but so far it seems to be pretty good for the price.

I ordered take-out on my way home after a long day at work and got the Tropical roll (smoked salmon skin, mango, cucumber, tobiko - 5.75$), mackerel nigiri (2.75$), and white tuna nigiri (2.75$).  I liked the Tropical roll, although it was hard to taste anything other than the smoked salmon skin.  Once in a while a bit of mango flavour would sneak in, but not as much as I would have hoped.  The white tuna wasn't that great; it was really fishy tasting.  The mackerel was also fishy tasting, but in that way that cheap mackerel is indeed fishy tasting, which I happen to like, so I did enjoy the mackerel.

The lady working there was super sweet, and brought me hot tea while I waited for my take out.  The place is pretty small and narrow, so it didn't look like it would be good for groups greater than 4 or so.  The early bird special looks intriguing, I'll definitely be back to try that some time.  While it wasn't the most amazing sushi I've ever had, it was quite good for the cheap price, plus there are a million things to choose from, and it's close to where I'm staying right now, so 4 stars from me.  Cash only!
author: emilie k.

description: The early bird special is the greatest when you need a sushi fix and none of your friends wanna go out. I always walk back home from the library and find a reason to stop in for the deal. Rice, miso soup, five pcs of any fish, seaweed salad and a roll. Insane. I want to eat it every nite.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
why did i allow myself to dine here? i went to the valencia one this evening in a moment of weakness. 2/3 of the way through my dinner, i noticed a cockroach on my glass - out of which i was drinking - that subsequently fell to the table. and sat there. i pointed it out to the waitress, discreetly, who looked somewhat wide-eyed, and then received the check for the full amount. after she asked me if i'd like to swap tables. i paid my portion. the roach didn't bother to move for me, i think it was waiting for me to get up so it could finish my meal.

granted, i wasn't expecting jardiniere finery, but camman. i think that roach is the only thing actually getting quality food in that place.

total dive. i'm glad i didn't have any of their raw fare.
author: Latrice B.

description: I went to We Be Sushi with some visitors from Japan. We had a variety of sushi which was very fresh and good. My Japanese visitors said that the sushi was authentic and very good. The restaurant owner also is apparently from Japan, and was very friendly.
author: Greg S.

description: I will never tire of We Be.  Probably the best sushi for the best price.  My fav. is their salmon sashimi (even though you shouldn't be able to screw this easy one up, believe me, some can) and salmon skin rolls.  Yumm!
author: Leann R.

description: Like the larger We Be Sushi south of 16th St, the food is outstanding.  This location is actually my favorite of the two, as the interior has a bit more character, the location is smaller, and the prices are a tiny bit cheaper, oddly enough.  The staff at both locations are always very nice, and again, the food is amazing.
author: Robert P.

description: We Be Sushi was a surprise on how great the food was and for the cost. Went here for lunch and really loved the rice with the the smoked salmon and the lunch special was excellent well worth the money. I have since visited numerous times. A great lunch spot!
author: Will C.

description: I went here with some colleagues for lunch to go. mehhh. Sushi not so good. Not so fresh, but edible. Places like this piss me off because it's like they're just not trying.
author: MissSkip Z.

description: I love this place.  This is not fine dining, but it's solid sushi for the money.  The fish is always fresh and tasty and none of the basics have ever disappointed.  The atmosphere is small and cozy.  I can usually chow down for $15-$20, which is amazing because i usually have my own personal sushi eating contest.  The prices are amazing and the fish is good quality.  Cash only.
author: Freedy H.

description:
they serve what they charge. very honest.

not the best sushi restaurant in the city. but, i don't think that's what they are trying to be anyways...

this is the place when you don't want to spend too much on sushi.
author: Superhiro M.

description: The three or four times I've been here I've found the sushi not to be that fresh - the death knell of sushi.  Soggy fish sucks.  Free appetizer carrot sticks are nice though!  Try Kiji nearby on Guerrero and 22nd Street instead. It's not as cheap as We Be, but you get what you pay for.
author: Mission D.

description: yeah, i went there and for starters the miso soup looks and tasstes mor like brown onion soup, the edamame is over cooked, to the point that the beans are hard again. and the chicken teryaki omg... truly awful it wasnt even chicken it was a 3 day left over rancid duck. the rice we had wasnt japanesse rice either, so yeah, i wouldnt consider this place, i rather eat a tamale out of a street stand...
author: ricardo m.

description: I love we be sushi!!!  Yes, its nothing fancy, but that's obvious from the decor.  It's affordable and it's good.  We always leave feeling satisfied.  It's good food for a good price...see you soon.
author: hannah b.

description: We Be Sushi is a great place for two friends to sit, have a beer and enjoy great sushi, for the price. I am leary of sushi joints whose prices are as low as a burger place, but I was pleasantly surprised at the quality for such an affordable evening. I would recommend the place for very casual dining. The one downfall: It's the same at almost every Sushi pllace, it takes forever to get your check when you're ready to leave. Otherwise, definitely worth it.
author: Sean M.

description: Well we've only been there once (today, lunch) , but we eat a lot of sushi, and I hafta say I don't understand the negative reviews here. The service was lovely and traditional, the maki and neguri was super fresh, and the prices were fine. What's not to like?  We're ready to go back again and try some different stuff on the menu. Definitely recommended.
author: Dexter N.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places.  The tempura is amazing.  The atmosphere is so-so but the staff has always been very friendly and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Kim s.

description: This is a regular haunt for us, as the price and food is always solid. I highly recommend their Shiro Maguro in Ponzu sauce.... yuuuuuummm, and the Hakushika Ginjo sake is really really good. Certainly not the finest dining in the city, but I just keep coming back, and leaving happy.
author: Isaac E.

description: I usually get take-out sushi from WeBe, and I love it! In the past, I've been to many pretentious, fancy Sushi Places, where you pay for the ambiance, rather than the food itself, and I always hated those "fake" places. WeBe is not pretentious at all, and just IS what it IS. It delivers good, honest, and tasty Sushi for very reasonable prices, and they are qualitatively consistent...  Since I love to (quantitatively) indulge sushi-wise, WeBe is  (financially) definitely a good place to get satisfied.
author: Bettina S.

description:
ok, whenever you read/write reviews about food, you really have to keep things in context....it's allll about expectation management.  
know what to expect and chances are, you'll be fine...this is especially true in san francisco where the food/atmosphere variety runs the gamut and it could get damn well confusing to pick a place.
we be sushi doesn't have the best sushi, but they are consistent with what they do.
i've been going to both locations on valencia for a number of years and i do think they are consistent.  ok....ok......so some of the food prep guys are chinese, but let's go back to consistency.  i am also nostalgic about this place because i remember waay back when they were trying to figure out what to name the place (i think guerrero still has the listing of contending names.....soooo gay and funny).
service is fast and friendly, it's a simple menu and food is relatively good bang for the buck.  it's a neighborhood place and they add small, small touches that are not fancy, but nice.  every meal gets miso and it's good and flavorful, i like how they add tofu to their salad and they add a sprinkle of sesame to their rice for subtle flavor.
those who appreciate subtle, simple flavors know what i mean - it's clean food, simple but fresh. 
my husband and i love to split everything for added variety...eee, plus there's something sexy about sharing food.  we like to order a salad or a veggie with miso dressing, an entree and a bunch of sushi.  add in a glass of dry sake and the chances of getting lucky that evening are highly probable. 
valencia location is condusive for very small groups or could be a good casual date place or eat alone.
author: Jackie C.

description: i have to say that i find we be sushi to have the worst sushi i've had in the city, and i've had my fair share.  the only reason i'm not giving it 1 star is that the people who run the place are extremely nice and i like the decor.  i really want to like this place, but whenever i've eaten there i haven't been able to actually eat my food...
author: genevieve g.

description: Has anyone else noticed that everyone with anything to say about a sushi restaurant turns into a fucking snob? Like all of a sudden everybody's a self-proclaimed sushi connoisseur. Seriously, every time a sushi spot enters the conversation, all I ever hear is how "it's not very good" qualified with some other modifier like, "it's cheap" or "it's convenient." The majority of reviews for We Be Sushi pretty much follow this exact formula of food criticism. But let's cut the crap because your average American doesn't know the first thing about sushi and likely neither does your average sushi chef given that more than eighty percent of Japanese restaurants (including sushi restaurants) in the United States are not authentically owned and operated by Japanese. That makes the odds of your average American's exposure to, and much less expertise of, the ancient and traditional art of sushi preparation quite unlikely. At least that's the rationale behind my consideration (or lack thereof) of people's attitudes about WeBe. Americans invented fast food for chrissake, so quit it with all the pretension to gourmandism already. Where's every self-taught gourmet when you need a recommendation for Ethiopian or French cuisine in the City? Most of these people would readily admit that they don't know where the fuck Addis Ababa is from Provence on a map before they chime in with their two cents about shitty Japanese food. You're cheap and you're hungry right? Then WeBe does the trick.
author: Jenn W.

description:
This review makes me sad, but it has to be done....

I used to really like this place but after last night's dinner I'm afraid I can only muster up 2 measly stars.  And the even sadder part of this is that it's almost entirely due to the incredibly awful service.  

The funny thing is that  we've always liked the service, but I'm thinking it must have to do with the night of week you go.  We always went on weekends before and we always had the soft spoken Japanese lady who wears her hair in pigtails. She's so nice! But last night was a Wednesday and we had possibly the worst waitress I've ever had in my life (okay that might be a stretch but you get the point).  First she brought our drinks to the wrong table.  Then she got visibly flustered and mad at me when I mistakenly asked for the "dinner special" instead of by its real name which escapes me now.  She also brought both of our dinners on the SAME plate. I don't have a problem with sharing space, but this just seemed bizarre and lazy on her end.  My boyfriend's explanation for her attitude and slip-ups was because she was too busy but I beg to differ-- have you seen this place? My bathroom is bigger (not exactly but you get what I'm saying) so I can't buy the "too busy" B.S.  And I also didn't appreciate her sudden wave of friendliness as we were finishing up.  This made her appear shallow and patronizing-- subtle acknowledgment of the badness without any substance to make it better.

The bill came to an almost even $20. I left a $3 tip.  I wish I could go back in time and subtract another dollar. Sounds harsh but thats how much she sucked guys!  As far as the food goes, you get what you pay for...its pretty inexpensive so of course its not going to be the best sushi the city has to offer. Last night seemed more mediocre than usual, very possibly due to the bad taste in my mouth courtesy of miss you-know-who.  I also don't care for cream cheese in my sushi and unfortunately that's the only kind they give you with the meal I ordered. It's pretty weak that you can't choose the kind of roll you want. 

Oh, and one more thing...as I was lying in bed last night, pondering the lameness, I realized she never brought my miso soup!
author: L. Renee D.

description: I think the only reason you'd want to eat here is that it's on Valencia. Kind of overpriced for what you get. I know sushi boat places with better sushi for about half the price.
author: Chris S.

description: I have walked by this place for the past 5 years and finally went in.  the diverse selection of rolls, especially the vegetarian rolls was great. I was not quite as impressed with the service.  The three stars are for unique atmosphere, value, satisfying selection of vegetarian rolls.
author: Kim R.

description: overpriced for their small portioned sushi. service was pretty good, standard. quality of the fish was neither atrocious nor stellar. wouldn't go back there again, it felt like a waste of time.
author: Lillian P.

description: i've had better.  the stars are for the space, mostly.  service was slow.  it's probably the closest sushi joint to where i live, but i will venture further to somewhere else.
author: Aimee B.

description: The best sushi I can afford with our budget and the staff is incredibly sweet. They always bring us extra miso soup for our daughter, often with an ice cub in it so she doesn't burn herself. The restaurant is super cozy and you really can't beat the price.
author: Sandy B.

description: When I go for sushi I first of all expect clean surroundings, polite service and well - presented food. This place was dark, cramped, and did not seem all that clean, and the service was harried. The food was OK. The presentation was about the sloppiest I have ever seen in a Japanese restaurant. The 20-something clientele did not seem to mind, though. There are a lot of places for sushi in San Francisco. For the life of me I do not see anything appealing about this place. And it is not that cheap. I will not go back.
author: Bob J.

description: i liked the sushi here.  i had the seaweed salad and california roll.  the service was mediocre, but the sushi was fresh and the salad was tangy and good.
author: Ann M.

description: not awful, but jeez, how is this place still in business given the great sushi in this city.  service and sushi was just plain bad.  supermarket sushi is about the same.  the price is cheap, but doesn't justify how bad it is.
author: N C.

description: An acquaintance says you should be skeptical of a $7.95 early bird sushi meal special (salad, soup, rice, 5 pieces of nigiri, and a roll).  That's a crazy value.  I live in the neighborhood and stop by for the early bird special a lot -- simple sushi.
author: G P.

description: I liked this place for what it is.  Reasonable sushi at a reasonable price.  The waitress/owner was very nice, the sushi was good; the rice okay at best..
author: Hal B.

description: Cozy decor and low prices is the best I can say about this place. I was put off by all sushi for months after being served 3  different rolls that had a strong fishy odor. How is it the chef could prepare this without getting a whiff, I wondered? Judging by the other reviews this might have been an isolated incident, but i won't be back.
author: Spikes T.

description: I used to go to this We Be Sushi often when I wasn't working for their early bird special (served from 5-7 (I believe)) which is $7.95 for miso soup, a salad, 5 pieces of your choice of nigiri and one california roll. A great deal! But fairly standard. And ultimately, not exciting or particularly excellent. The great deal prevented me from exploring the rest of the menu. This was remedied on this past Sunday night when I went as part of a group of six people and tried the 49'er roll, the dragon roll and the catch of the day roll. All of those were really delicious: the 49'er had plentiful salmon; the dragon had big cuts of unagi wrapped around it. The enormous platter that we ordered arrived within 15 minutes and the service was fantastic in general especially considering the size of our party...I was very pleasantly surprised. They're not really a "4 star" restaurant, but this was definitely a "4 star" experience.
author: Lauren S.

description: i went here on saturday night, it was probably close to 9ish. the four of us were seated right away, which is great.  i thought it was funny that my tea was served in a mug that looked like it was a free giveaway promo mug from some random place. there were lots of selections of different rolls, and my friends ordered a bunch for us.  if you are vegetarian, this is a good place to go, cuz there's lots of veggie rolls there. a little bit too many for me, because it limited the amount of actual fish sushi rolls. it also came with miso soup which was good, and endame which is always great. the rolls were good not great actually just ok. ive had better a lot of places. the thing i didnt like about this place was that these mariachi guys kept walking in, and playing right in my ear. then wanted $ for that afterwards. it was very hard to hear the conversation with that going on... at the same time, i suppose its a bit of mission character... mexican players in a sushi restaurant. overall, it was ok, but i'd never purposely go back here again, unless i was hungry and right next to it, like we were then. it's basic, but not great, cash only sushi place. i still had fun tho at sushi with the girls. :)
author: Merredith L.
